root: ^Detective! [He arches one thin eyebrow, questioningly]. To what do I owe the pleasure?

c-1: ^[He smirks]. My, my, rather forward, aren't you, Detective?
c-2: ^What, has there been a murder, and I'm a suspect?

Murder: ^Mr. Willoughby...! How terrible. He was supposed represent me in court, you know...

s: ^Tell me a little bit about yourself.
^Where were you on the night of the murder?
^What do you think of Delilah Winters?
^What do you think of Sam Soapley?

Self: ^My name is Toby Wilson. Veteran soldier, entrepreneur, an ace at cards and golf... free from any troubles... except one tiny thing.

s: ^Can you tell me more about your hobbies?
^Can you tell me more about your career?

Trial: ^Oh, just this whole affair with my wife... they're saying I killed her! Me! Such an innocent and beautiful soul, she was, my Imogen... I shudder at even the thought!
SelfHub: ^[His eyes flick ever side-to-side as you look at him].

s: ^Cut the crap. We know you killed her.
^That's a shame... well, there's always time to move on, you know... (flirt).
^Why would they think you killed her?

c-1: ^I know, Detective. [He blinks at you coyly].

Hobbies: ^Hmm.... let's see. I go golfing every Saturday with some of my army buddies... and spend most of the rest of my time at the card table. And I do enjoy spending time at the gun range, I will say.

c-0: ^Poison? Why, no, nothing... well, perhaps a little... they taught us the basics in Basic, you know! I'd ask Ms. Winters, the secretary. I know she's married to a pharmacist.
c-1: ^I win some, I lose some... I would say, overall, though, I'm quite brilliant.

Career: ^I served for some time in the Great War... a horrible affair, though for a just cause, which gave me some comfort... but I injured my leg terribly and was sent home early. [He wiggles the cane at his side to demonstrate].
^As for entrepreneuring.... I've taken it up since. Car shops, stock brokering, even a bakery...! Unfortunately, my businesses tend to go belly up... It's like a curse!

c-0: ^I'm just not that good with money... it slips through my fingers, I'm afraid.

^Oh, just the usual legal fees. [His tail twitches nervously]. Though he was hell-bent on increasing them... I kept trying to tell him that I wouldn't be able to afford his services soon, but he didn't listen. Now, I suppose, it doesn't matter, rest his soul.

Finances: ^Ah... the army pension only pays so much and as much as I hate to admit it, I sometimes do lose at cards. And with the legal fees... [He looks distressed even talking about it].

c-2: ^Just drop it, okay? My finances are... in an embarrassing state. Unfortunately, I've been blessed with the burden of pride, and so it pains me to talk about them at length.

s: ^Would you kill Mr. Willoughby over it?

c-0: ^Don't think you'll force a confession out of me so easily, Detective.

Bakery: ^Why is that curious? Yes, all manner of pastries, pies, cakes, croissants, sweet buns... we ran out of business because we couldn't afford sugar anymore.

s: ^A pie was found at the murder scene.

c-0: ^Oh, nowhere in particular. [He fiddles with the token in his hand].
^Just a little thing I picked up from the gambling parlor, is all. Nothing special. But I think it's lucky.

s: ^Won't stop you from going to jail.

c-1: ^Oh, stop. You're going to make a man blush.

c-2: ^Oh, I dabbled. Always like to know a little bit about the business, see. Nothing too crazy.

s: ^Remind him a pie was found at the murder scene.

Pie: ^We've been out of business for years!
Crap: ^And how are you so certain? Have you been following the case?

c-0: ^Then you can't say anything. They say I poisoned her! Her! Little old me, who knows nothing of poisons? Not to mention my love for my wife...
c-1: ^Oh, well, then you know there was no way I could have poisoned her! I wasn't even at home when she died.

s: ^Lily extract is a slow acting poison...

c-0: ^Oh, I didn't know that. [His tail twitches].
^Does this have anything to do with the case at hand?

s: ^Mr. Willoughby was poisoned in the same way.

c-0: ^An awful coincidence, yes. Not proof that I carried out either crime.

Eye: ^No! Of course not. I will mourn my dear departed Imogen for a thousand sunsets and sunrises.
^(if flirt is high enough) Though... perhaps you might end the mourning earlier...

s: ^I'd be happy to help you forget her (flirt).

c-0: ^Of course I'm sure! Anything you may have heard about me and any others is just baseless rumormongering. These fellows... like that Soapley fellow... I am afraid they just don't have enough to do! They must make things up to amuse themselves
^Yes, that Soapley fellow. Don't believe a thing he says. I've never trusted him. He has shifty eyes....

c-1: ^Maybe there comes a time to move on.

Guilt: ^Oh, you know... they always like to blame the husband in cases like these. And, they said I had a motive too: she had a life-insurance policy, you see... I got some for the both of us when my finances were in a better condition. That army paranoia never leaves you.

s: ^Cut the crap. We know you killed her.

c-1: ^She had this ex-lover, you see... a horrible, jealous, unstable man. We served in the corps together... he took pleasure in murder. It is obvious to me he would have done it. He says he was out of the country, but it is so easy to falsify plane records these days...

s: ^Cut the crap. We know you killed her.

c-0: ^Thank you, Detective. I knew I could count on you to be a reasonable man.

Procedings: ^Ah... now that Mr. Willoughby is dead, rather terribly. I will have to find another lawyer who knows all the facts like he did... and does not twist them for his own benefit, as so many lawyers do... It's rare to find a trustworthy lawyer. A profession of liars, made by liars, for liars. Willoughby was one of the few I respected.

s: ^How is it going in the courtroom?

c-0: ^The trial is due to start next week... though perhaps I can delay it, out of respect for my attorney's passing... it is policy, you see.

s: ^Would you kill him to delay the trial?

c-0: ^Don't think you'll force a confession out of me so easily, Detective.
c-1: ^Ah... I suppose I am. Forgive me, Detective. I ramble much these days.... half in the realm of the dead and departed. Those prosecutors, I must say, are tricky fellows... they have woven quite a case against me. Mr. Willoughby was my only hope of breaking through their slander and lies.

s: ^Tell him you hope he loses the trial.

Imogen: ^Oh, such a soul was Imogen... my late wife. You would not believe it! She was selfless and kind... she worked with an orphanage nearby, and liked to knit... this tie, you see, she made it! I keep it on myself as a reminder of the terrors of this world.

c-1: ^No... poor Imogen. Cursed with a barren womb. We were thinking of fostering but her sainted life was cut short too soon... [He wipes away a tear. You can't tell if it's real or not].
^Remember, I've been through this rigamaroll all before... with my wife and all. Kindly remind me of the times?

Remind: ^Ah... At 6 o'clock, I came home from the office - I'm starting an insurance business, see... and I went over to that gambling parlor - the shady one - that I frequent sometimes, played a game or two of poker, won some money, stumbled home, drunk... walked past this place on my way here. And voila! A crime scene. In which I was a suspect of course.

s: ^When did you arrive at the apartment?
^Did you see anything suspicious when you arrived?

c-0: ^Oh, I don't know. Wasn't keeping track, you know how it goes. Probably... 10 or 11?

s: ^Were you the first on the scene?
^Ask him if he saw anything suspicious there.

c-0: ^Oh, no. There were some first responders there already - they'd heard a banging on the roof and suspected a break-in. Soapley was already there, I think, inside... and then Ms. Winters came running up, all aflutter...

s: ^Ask him if he saw anything suspicious there.

c-2: ^[He pulls out a fistful of poker chips from his pocket. They are undated - it's impossible to tell if they were used today]. Here.
c-3: ^Oh, why, you can take a chance on me.

Sight: ^I mean, Soapley was there, hanging around the doorway... and Ms. Winters, she came it from quite an odd angle, from almost behind the house... I think it could be either one of them, judging by position. Soapley was in the house to kill him, and Ms. Winters ran from the scene and came back for whatever godforsaken reason - guilt, perhaps. Who knows!

s: ^Who do you think would be more likely to do it?
^Who do you think would be more likely to be the killer

Likely: ^Oh, well, I don't know. Ms. Winters had some secrets she didn't want knowing about. Mr. Soapley could be working for the mob... how strange.

c-0: ^Let's just say... she hasn't been an honest woman.
^Just speculation, of course. Place and time, place and time.

c-1: ^Just speculation, of course. Place and time, place and time.

c-0: ^Let's just say... she hasn't been an honest woman.

Enemies: ^Can't say I know of any enemies, specifically. There was this case, though, a few years back, where he defended a known member of the mob... he got death threats over it, see. It was all in the papers. In fact they say someone ever really tried to kill him - the mother of a man who had been slaughtered by the mobster Willoughby was defending. Perhaps they finally succeeded.

s: ^And where did you hear about that?

c-2: ^Oh, the papers. Everyone knows the papers are a reliable source!

s: ^Ask is there's anyone else that could be targeting Willoughby.
^Ask if there were more recent enemies.
^Ask if the mob he defended had rivals.

Target: ^Oh, yes... certainly. I'm not sure exactly who, but Willoughby has defended more scumbags than you'd imagine... certainly he has enemies.

s: ^Doesn't that mean you're also a scumbag?

Scumbag: ^Oh, maybe. [He smirks]. I wouldn't say so.

c-0: ^Well, mabye I am a bit of a scumbag after all... [His smile lingers].
c-1: ^I give to the poor! What more do I have to say?

Rivals: ^Oh, certainly. Maybe they could have even employed an assasin... come to think of it, I think those guys - the rivals, I mean... I think those guys run this gambling parlor I've been to.

c-0: ^Oh, because I saw Mr. Soapley there the other night, I think... Don't tell him I said that.

s: ^Ask if he thinks Soapley is with the mob.
^Ask if he thinks Soapley is with the mob.

c-1: ^Oh, there's no harm in consuming their product, Detective!

s: ^Ask if he thinks Soapley is with the mob.

Soapley: ^Oh, maybe... he was talking with them behind the counter of the bar himself, all familiar-like. Just thought I'd let you know.

c-0: ^Oh, well, you can draw that conclusion for yourself, Detective. I'm not conspiracy theorist.

Willoughby: ^Oh, Willoughby. A fine fellow, a good attorney, what more is there to say?

s: ^Did you know him on a more personal level?

Fight: ^Oh, no, I mean... hmmm... On occasion we clashed because of well... financial differences. But I'd never kill him over it. He was my best chance to get off scott free.
Differences: ^Oh, he wanted to upcharge me because my case was too hard... it's a load of shit, pardon my French. Nothing too major.
Other: ^They're all just being dramatic, you know. Everyone around here was so dramatic all the time - Delilah and Sam! Sometimes I thought even sensible, stand up Mr. Willoughby was going to join in the insanity!

^No... those folks are all messed up in the head, that's what. All twisted up in there. They think I'm "sly," they thinking I'm "lying," they think I'm "skulking." All I am's an army guy who's still adjustin' to society. Nobody really understands...

c-0: ^Believe what you want, Detective. I don't care.
c-1: ^Later, darling. For now, we've got to understand this murder. [He smirks at you].

Personal: ^Personal? No, I can't really say I did. Not in the slightest. Had tea with him a few times while seeking his council, but you know, nothing more than the occasional.

s: ^I thought you were loyal to your dead wife.

c-1: ^Please, Detective. You're going to distract me.

Material: ^Oh, I don't know.... she can be quite unstable, on occasion. Yelling, screaming... it's all a front, that lovely face... hiding...

s: ^Ask if she was ever aggressive toward Willoughby.

c-0: ^Oh, I don't know - I never saw. But behind his back... she said such awful things to me about him. Apparently he hoardes all the fees for himself!
^I don't know why she'd lie now. To protect him from beyond the grave, oooh!

Loyal: ^Oh, but a man can have eyes, can't he?

s: ^Is there anything between you two I should know about?

c-0: ^Oh, stop. You know how to make a man blush.

s: ^Ask him if there's anything else to her.

Else: ^There's a lot more to her than her looks, of course. She's smart, good at her job... but unstable too. Dramatic. Always lying, always trying to stir up trouble... a real gossip. Maybe worse.

s: ^Ask him about his relationship with her.
^Ask him how you know he isn't lying.

c-1: ^Oh, it's hard. I know she puts on that act, the one with the eyes... but just know, what lurks behind... it's not pretty, that's all I can say.

Relations: ^I'm going to be honest with you now, Detective: brutally. It hurts my case, but in truth, Ms. Winters and I had been having a physical relationship for some time. Oh, it hurts to admit... but I was so lonely without my Imogen, and she is dead... and Delilah looks just like her...
Start: ^She came on to me, that's for sure. Crying about how distant her husband is, and she just wants to be loved... what a mess. I fell for it, of course. Everyone falls for the sob story. Even a man in mourning like me. Especially a mourning man like me... a lonely man.

s: ^I could help make you less lonely. (flirt)

c-1: ^Because I was lonely, like I said. And she was there... and kind... and willing to distract me from my troubles.

Troubles: ^Oh, my dead wife, my money troubles, even some of the losses at cards... not that I often lose. All a distraction.

c-0: ^Of course not! [He scratches the back of his head nervously].

Ongoing: ^Ongoing... well... it's complicated. She's always breaking things off with me and then wanting to get back together... it's tumultous, a thing of passion. We're on one of our off phases right now.

c-2: ^Oh, only a few months. Since Mr. Willoughby took me as his client. That's where we met. Started a few weeks in to the preparation of his defense.

BreakUp: ^It was this whole thing, see... she saw a shadow on the wall, freaked out, and started screaming that someone had seen us! She told me we had to break it off because her husband couldn't know... but it was just the shadow of a passing car. Nothing I said could convince her of it!

s: ^Whose shadow did she think it was?
^Are you sure it was a passing car?
^Anything else that triggered the break up?

c-1: ^As sure as I am sure my name is Toby Wilson.

c-0: ^Who do you take me for? A liar? That's the sort of thing Delilah would say.

Drama: ^Mmmm... she was always so dramatic, making up stories and jumping at shadows. Too much to handle! Always switching up on me. In love day, mad with rage the next... honestly, maybe this time I won't get back together with her.

s: ^Ask who Delilah thought the shadow was.

c-0: ^Oh, Detective... [He bats his eyelashes at you].

s: ^Ask who Delilah thought the shadow was.

Shadow: ^Why, she thought it was Willoughby! Imagine that!

s: ^Do you think she could have killed him?

c-0: ^Oh... it would be a surprise... but she was always so paranoid about her reputation.

Like: ^A tumultous thing. Always on and off again... truly dreadful.

s: ^Do you think Delilah could be a murderer?

c-0: ^It's hard to imagine... she's such a delicate woman... but in the storm of passion, one can do anything, hmm? And she might have reason to.

Sam: ^Sam Soapley... the man's butler. I must say, I'm far more familiar with him than I should be.
Mean: ^I saw him outside of the workplace, I think. Doing something he perhaps would not want to be caught doing. Though maybe it wasn't him... my eyesight is failing, after all...

s: ^Ask him about his failing eyesight and the army.
^Ask him what he thought he saw.

c-0: ^Oh, maybe it was from the chemicals and weapons I worked with in the army... but it didn't happen until after I'd already come home.

s: ^Ask him what he thought he saw.
^Ask him what he thought he saw.

Saw: ^I was out at the gambling parlor, see... with some of my buddies. And, well, I know that place isn't exactly run by reputable people... not that I have anything to do with them other than partake in their business.
^Well... I saw him - Soapley, I mean - walking behind the bar like he was part of the staff... I think he's with the mob!

s: ^Speculate maybe Sam could have been there for a more innocent reason.
^Ask if he thinks it makes sense for Sam to be a mobster.

Innocent: ^A more innocent reason? Like what? He was picking up alcohol from the mobsters to give to Mr. Willoughby?

s: ^Point out that he's jumping to conclusions.
^Ask him why he plays at a mob-run gambling parlor if he's so innocent.

c-0: ^What other conclusion should I jump to?

s: ^It seems as if you're trying to put suspicion on him.

c-0: ^Are you trying to accuse me of something?

c-1: ^Oh, I think there's no shame in taking advantage of the opportunities you're given to have some fun. Working with the mob on the other hand... that's a whole other ballgame, if you take my meaning. He may even have some blood on his hands.

s: ^Ask him if he thinks Soapley would have killed Mr. Willoughby.
^Ask him if it makes sense for Soapley to be a mobster.

c-0: ^I don't know... I just think Soapley's a suspicious fellow, is all...

Mobster: ^It's always the quiet ones, isn't it? And besides, he cuts quite a hulking figure... the sort mobsters always possess, hmm?
^All I can say is while I didn't know the man enough to be certain, this city is full of scummy people hiding in plain sight... it would make sense for Soapley to be one of them.

s: ^Ask him if he thinks Soapley killed Willoughby.

c-0: ^I don't know... I just think Soapley's a suspicious fellow, is all...

Enthusiastic: ^I'm so glad you agree with me, Detective... I was worried you'd think it was just slander and lies...

s: ^Do you think he could have killed Mr. Willoughby?
^Do you think Mr. Willoughby knew about his involvement?

c-0: ^I don't know... I just think Soapley's a suspicious fellow, is all...
c-1: ^Oh, probably not. That poor man was clueless... I was thinking of telling him, but I'm sure Soapley spotted me. I have no desire to die.

s: ^Do you think Sam Soapley could have killed Mr. Willoughby?

c-0: ^I don't know... I just think Soapley's a suspicious fellow, is all...

How: ^Visited a few times to discuss business with poor Willoughby. Soapley was there, just bringing the tea... seemed like a well-meaning fellow at the time. Quite a gardener. I hear he grows even poisonous plants in there.

s: ^Ask him if he ever visited the garden.
^Ask him why he said "at the time."

c-0: ^The garden? Only once. Saw some flowers I recognized as poisonous from my army time...
^Oh, poisons? Only a passing familiarity from my army time, that's all.
^The murder weapon? [His tail twitches in shock]. Oh, that's not a good look for old Soapley at all...

s: ^Ask if he's trying to put suspicions on Sam.

SamSus: ^Oh, no, no... that poor man... could he have done it?

c-0: ^I don't know... maybe... he is a seedy sort, in secret. But I really can't say.
c-1: ^Are you trying to accuse me of something?
